Institute for Catalysis Hokkaido University N-21 W-10 Sapporo 001-0021 Japan Graphical abstract Hydrolysis of water-insoluble esters is an industrially important but challenging reaction, because the esters are mostly present in oil droplets on water during the reaction. On the basis of the screening results for hydrolysis of a water-insoluble ester, 3-phenylpropionate, on/in water by 25 types of heterogeneous and homogenous catalysts, we have found that Hβ zeolite with a moderate Si/Al ratio (Si/Al=75), Hβ-75, is an effective and reusable catalyst for hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters. The hydrolysis of esters with different sizes is studied by Hβ and HZSM5 zeolites with different Si/Al ratios, and the results show the hydrophobicity, pore size and number of Brønsted acid sites are critical factors affecting the catalytic activity for this system. Kinetic and adsorption studies show that the high yields by Hβ-75 are due to preferential interaction of the hydrophobic zeolite pore with hydrophobic esters over polar molecules (carboxylic acids, water, alcohols) and transfer of the carboxylic acids to the oil droplets on water, both of which inhibit the reverse reaction (esterification of the carboxylic acids). Keywords Hydrolysis Esters Zeolites Hydrophobic interaction Aqueous media 1 Introduction Hydrolysis of esters is a fundamental organic transformation in the synthesis of various chemicals. Conventionally, the hydrolysis of esters is carried out with homogeneous Brønsted bases such as NaOH [1], which suffers from low atom-efficiency due to the use of stoichiometric amount of the base as well as the use of stoichiometric amount of acids to isolate the carboxylic acids in the workup. Potentially, Brønsted acids-catalyzed hydrolysis of esters can offer a greener route to carboxylic acids. Generally, esters are less hydrophilic than the corresponding carboxylic acids and alcohols. In addition, conventional homogeneous Brønsted acid catalysts are soluble in water. Hence, homogeneous Brønsted acid catalysts can promote the reverse esterification of carboxylic acids and alcohols in water, which can result in low yields of the carboxylic acids and alcohols for the Brønsted acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of water-insoluble esters. Heterogeneous Brønsted acid catalysts with a relatively hydrophobic nature [2,3], including zeolites with a high Si/Al ratio [2–4], salts of heteropoly acid [2,3,5–9], metal oxides [10] and acidic resins [11] have been shown to catalyze the hydrolysis of esters in water. The hydrophobic surface or pore of the water-tolerant solid Brønsted acid catalysts will interact preferentially with the esters over hydrophilic products (carboxylic acids and alcohols), and thus, they will be promising catalysts for hydrolysis of esters in water. However, most of the previous reports [2–11] of the hydrophobic solid acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of esters tested only hydrophilic esters (mostly ethyl acetate), and the activity of the solid catalysts was lower than the conventional Brønsted acids. For example, Okuhara et al. [6] compared the activity of various acid catalysts for hydrolysis of ethyl acetate in water and showed that sulfonic acid (H2SO4) and p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA) showed more than 10 times higher reaction rates (per weight of the catalyst) than hydrophobic solid acids, including zeolites, heteropoly acids, metal oxides and acidic resins. Contrary to the water-soluble ester (ethyl acetate), water-insoluble esters are mostly present at oil droplets on water, and hence, the solid catalyst suspended in water cannot be effective for hydrolysis of the water-insoluble esters. In nature, an enzyme named carboxylesterase or carboxylic-ester hydrolase catalyzes hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters in water [12]. The active site of this enzyme is located at the bottom of a hydrophobic narrow tunnel [12]. As for artificial catalysts, to our knowledge, only two methods have been reported to show high yields for the hydrolysis of water-insoluble esters in the presence of excess amount of water, and both of the systems adopt Brønsted acid sites at hydrophobic environments [13–15]. One successful example is N,N-diarylammonium pyrosulfate catalyst reported by Ishihara et al. [13] In the presence of excess amount of water, the homogeneous Brønsted acid catalyst forms reverse micelle in organic layer to promote the hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters on the surface of the oil-in-water emulsion, resulting in high conversions for various hydrophobic esters [13]. However, the method has drawbacks of difficulties in catalyst/products separation and catalyst reuse. Another example is a octadecylsilane-treated HZSM5 zeolite [14,15] as a water-tolerant heterogeneous Brønsted acid catalyst. The immobilization of the alkyl-group on the outer surface of zeolites increases the hydrophobicity of the zeolites [16–18] and hence increases the catalytic activity of HZSM5 for hydrolysis of the esters [14,15]. However, the method suffers from serious drawbacks of limited substrate scope due to a narrow pore size of HZSM5, necessity of toluene as a co-solvent and no report of catalyst reuse. It is well established that aluminosilicate zeolites with a high Si/Al ratio, so-called high-silica zeolites, have high hydrophobicity due to nonpolar nature of the Si-O-Si surface [3,4,19–21]. Among various commercially available zeolites, proton-exchanged ∗BEA zeolite (Hβ) has relatively large pore size and three-dimensional pore structure, which arrow rapid diffusion of bulky organic substrates and products. The strong Brønsted acid sites in the hydrophobic pore of Hβ will be effective for acid-catalyzed reactions of hydrophobic substrates. Recently, high-silica Hβ zeolites have been shown to catalyze organic transformations in the presence of water [22,23]. We hypothesized that hydrophobic and large pore Hβ zeolites may be effective for the catalytic hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters in the presence of excess amount of water. We report herein that a high-silica Hβ zeolite shows higher activity than conventional homogeneous acid catalysts and the water-tolerant Brønsted [3] and Lewis [24–26] acid catalysts for hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters in the presence of excess amount of water. Catalytic results show catalyst reusability and wide applicability of this method. To study critical factors affecting the catalytic activity, fundamental studies are also carried out for Hβ and HZSM5 zeolites with different Si/Al ratio and alkyl-group immobilized Hβ. 2 Experimental 2.1 General Commercially available organic compounds (from Tokyo Chemical Industry or Aldrich) were used without further purification. GC (Shimadzu GC-2014) and GCMS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010) analyses were carried out with Ultra ALLOY+-1 capillary column (Frontier Laboratories Ltd.) with N2 and He as the carrier. Column chromatography was performed with silica gel 60 (spherical, 63–210μm, Kanto Chemical Co. Ltd.). Molecular sieves 4Å (MS4Å) were dehydrated at 100°C. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The zeolites used in this study are designated as Hβ-x, where x denotes the Si/Al ratio of the Hβ zeolite. Hβ-75 (JRC-Z-HB150, originally supplied from Clariant), HZSM5-45 (JRC-Z5-90H(1)), HMOR-45 (JRC-Z-HM90, originally supplied from Clariant), TiO2 (JRC-TIO-4), CeO2 (JRC-CEO-3), amorphous SiO2-Al2O3 (JRC-SAL-2, Al2O3 content=13.75wt%, surface area=560m2 g−1) were supplied from Catalysis Society of Japan. Hβ-20 (HSZ-940HOA), Hβ-255 (HSZ-980HOA), HZSM5-20 (HSZ-840HOA) and HY-50 (HSZ-385HUA) were commercially purchased from Tosoh Co. HZSM5-75 and HZSM5-300 were supplied from N.E. CHEMCAT Co. Niobic acid (HY-340) was kindly supplied by CBMM, and Nb2O5 was prepared by calcination of the niobic acid at 500°C for 3h. SiO2 (Q-10) was supplied from Fuji Silysia Chemical Ltd. ZrO2 and SnO2 were prepared by calcination (500°C, 3h) of ZrO2⋅nH2O and H2SnO3 (Kojundo Chemical Laboratory Co., Ltd.). Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 was prepared by titrating H3PW12O40 (Nippon Inorganic Color and Chemicals Co.) by aqueous solution of Cs2CO3 (0.10moldm−3) with vigorous stirring, followed by centrifuging and drying at 200°C. Montmorillonite K10 clay and sulfonic resins (Amberlyst-15 and Nafion-SiO2 composite) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Scandium(III) trifluoromethanesulfonate, Sc(OTf)3, and p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA) were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry. Octadecyltriethoxysilane-treated Hβ-20 (OD-Hβ-20) was prepared by refluxing a mixture of the Hβ-20 (1g, dried at 100°C) and octadecyltriethoxysilane (0.2mmol) in dry toluene (5mL) for 6h, followed by filtering and washing with toluene and acetone, and by drying at 100°C for 1h. The number of the octadecyl-groups determined by the CO2 formation in the temperature programmed oxidation analysis (25–500°C under O2 flow) was 0.09mmolg−1. 2.3 In situ IR The pyridine-adsorption IR (infrared) study was carried with JASCO FT/IR-4200 spectrometer equipped with an MCT detector using a flow-type IR cell connected to a flow reaction system. The IR disk of the sample (40mg, 20mm ϕ) was first dehydrated under He flow at 500°C, and then a background spectrum was taken under He flow at 200°C. Then, pyridine (0.3mmolg−1) was introduced to the sample, followed by purging by He for 600s, and by IR measurement of adsorbed pyridine at 200°C. 2.4 Catalytic tests The heterogeneous catalysts, stored under ambient conditions, were used for catalytic reactions without any pretreatment. Typically, ester (1mmol), 1mL H2O and 10mg of catalysts and a magnetic starter bar were added to a reaction vessel (Pyrex pressure tube, 13mL), and the mixture was heated at 130°C under air with stirring at 300rpm. For the catalytic tests in Table 1 and kinetic study, conversions and yields were determined by GC-FID using n-dodecane as an internal standard as follows. After completion of the reaction, acetone (7mL) was added to the mixture, and the catalyst was separated by centrifugation. Then, n-dodecane (0.2mmol) was added to the reaction mixture, and the mixture was analyzed by GC-FID and GC–MS. The GC-FID sensitivities of the products were determined using commercial carboxylic acids or the isolated products after the reaction. For some of the products in Tables 2 and 3 , we determined isolated yields of the carboxylic acids as follows. After the filtration of the catalyst, followed by washing the catalyst with acetone (6mL), and by evaporation, the product was isolated by column chromatography using silica gel 60 (spherical, 63–210μm, Kanto Chemical Co. Ltd.) with hexane/ethyl acetate (60/40–80/20) as the eluting solvent, followed by analyses by 1H NMR, 13C NMR and GC–MS equipped with the same column as GC-FID. 2.5 Adsorption experiments Liquid phase adsorption experiments (Figs. 7, 10 and 1) were carried out as follows. Organic molecules (1mmol of 1-pentanol, methyl 3-phenylpropionate, ethyl acetate and acetic acid) with 1mL water were stirred with solid adsorbent (0.1g) for 24h at room temperature, followed by centrifugation to separate the solids from the liquid. Then, acetone (6mL) and the internal standard (0.2mmol n-dodecane) were added to the liquid, which was analyzed by GC-FID. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Acidity characterization of Hβ-75 and HZSM5-75 Fig. 1 shows the ring-stretching region of the IR spectra for pyridine adsorbed on Hβ-75 and HZSM5-75. A strong band at 1543cm−1 is assignable to the pyridinium ion (PyH+) [27] formed by the reaction of pyridine with Brønsted acid site of the zeolites. As expected, intensities of the band at 1454cm−1 due to the coordinatively bound pyridine on Lewis acid [27] are relatively weak. Previously, we determined the integrated molar extinction coefficient (1.26cmμmol−1) of the PyH+ in zeolites [27]. Using this coefficient combined with the area intensities of the bands at 1543cm−1, the numbers of Brønsted acid sites in Hβ-75 and HZSM5-75 were calculated to be 0.13mmolg−1 and 0.19mmolg−1, respectively. 3.2 Catalyst screening In the literature, most of the previous reports [4–11] on hydrolysis of esters by heterogeneous catalysts adopted hydrolysis of ethyl acetate, which resulted in low yields probably due to the reverse esterification of acetic acid with ethanol. First, we tested the hydrolysis of ethyl acetate in water (Fig. 2 ). It was confirmed that a high-silica Hβ zeolite (Hβ-75) showed lower yield of acetic acid than conventional homogeneous Brønsted acids (H2SO4 and PTSA). Then, we tested hydrolysis of methyl 3-phenylpropionate (1a) to 3-phenyl-propionic acid (2a) as a model reaction of a water insoluble ester. Table 1 lists the yields of 2a for the hydrolysis of 1a (1mmol) with H2O (1mL) for 20h in the presence of 10mg of the catalysts. The ester (oil droplet) was on water, and the solid catalysts were suspended in water during the reaction. During heating of the closed reactor (Pyrex pressure tube) at 130°C, the water was refluxing, so the reaction temperature was lower than 130°C. We confirmed that the thermal reaction in the absence of catalyst showed no conversion of 1a (entry 1). We tested the model reaction with 25 types of catalysts including heterogeneous (entries 2–23) and homogeneous (entries 24–26) acid catalysts. The HZSM5 catalysts reported in an earlier study for this reaction [4] showed low yields of 0–9%. The activity of Hβ (entries 6–8) and HZSM5 (entries 2–5) depended on the Si/Al ratio, and the zeolites with intermediate Si/Al values, Hβ-75 (entry 7, 84% yield) and HZSM5-75 (entry 4, 9% yield), showed high activity. HY-50 (entry 10) and HMOR-45 (entry 11) gave moderate yields of 46% and 59%. The activity of different zeolites changed in the order of Hβ-75>HY-50>HMOR-45≫HZSM5-75. Comparison of the pore sizes of Hβ (7.6Å×7.3Å), HY (7.4Å), HMOR (7.0Å×6.5Å) and HZSM5 (5.6Å×5.3Å) with the diameter of the minimum cross-section of 1a (6.8Å×5.2Å) indicates that low activity of HZSM5 is due to smaller size of the zeolite pore than that of the substrate. This suggests that the zeolite-catalyzed hydrolysis of 1a is an intrazeolite reaction. The yield (79%) for the octadecyltriethoxysilane-treated Hβ-20 (OD-Hβ-20 in entry 9) was higher than that for Hβ-20 (entry 6, 63%). This suggests that hydrophobic nature of zeolites is also an important activity controlling factor in the present catalytic system. Non-zeolitic metal oxides (entries 12–21) and commercial acidic resins (entries 22,23) were also screened under the same conditions. A non-zeolitic aluminosilicate, SiO2-Al2O3 mixed oxide (entry 12), gave only 2% yield, and amorphous SiO2 (entry 13) showed no activity. ZrO2, TiO2 and SnO2, showed low yields (14–25%). CeO2, Nb2O5 and niobic acid were reported to act as water-tolerant Lewis acid catalysts [24,25]. A heteropoly acid salt, Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40, was reported to be a water-tolerant Brønsted acid catalyst [3,6]. These water-tolerant heterogeneous catalysts (entries 17–20) showed only 9–29% yields for the hydrolysis of 1a. Commercially available acid catalysts (entries 21–23), including montmorillonite K10 clay, Amberlyst-15 (acidic resins with sulfonic acid groups) and Nafion/SiO2 composite showed low to moderate yields of 10–48%. Conventional Brønsted acids (H2SO4 and PTSA) and Sc(OTf)3 as a water-tolerant homogeneous Lewis acid catalyst [26] were chosen as model homogeneous catalysts. These catalysts showed moderate yields (53–58%) for the reaction. It is important to note that Hβ-75 shows higher yield than H2SO4 and PTSA under the same catalyst weight conditions, which is a rare example of a heterogeneous catalyst with higher activity (per catalyst weight) than the conventional Brønsted acids for hydrolysis of esters. Summarizing the results in Table 1, Hβ-75 and OD-Hβ-20 are found to be two of the most effective catalysts for the hydrolysis of the water-insoluble ester 1a in the presence of excess water. These catalysts have three common properties: (1) hydrophobicity due to high Si/Al ratio or immobilized alkyl-groups, (2) three-dimensional large pore structure, and (3) strong Brønsted acid sites in the pore. Considering the fact that the catalyst powder was in water phase, these results suggest that Brønsted acid sites in a hydrophobic environment are efficient catalytic sites for the hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters on/in water. 3.3 Catalytic performance of Hβ-75 and OD-Hβ-20 In order to explore the generality and scope of the present catalytic method, we carried out the hydrolysis of various hydrophobic esters to the corresponding carboxyl acids with the most effective catalyst, Hβ-75, on/in water for 24h. Table 2 lists the yields of the carboxyl acids. Linear aliphatic esters, including methyl laurate (entry 1), ethyl n-octanoate (entry 2) and propyl hexanoate (entry 3), methyl 3-phenylpropionate 1a (entry 4) and a bulky ester with a naphthyl group (entry 5) were hydrolyzed to the corresponding carboxyl acids with high yields (85–93%). For the hydrolysis of methyl laurate, the 90% yield corresponds to the turnover number (TON) of 723 per number of Brønsted acid sites of Hβ-75. The TON of 723 is more than 8 times higher than that of the recently reported homogeneous catalyst [13]. Hydrolysis of an ester with a CC double bond, methyl cinnamate (entry 6), was also succeeded. Methyl benzoate (entry 7) and its derivatives with electron-donating (entries 8,9) and electron-withdrawing functional groups (entry 10), tert-butyl p-toluate (entry 11) and heteroaromatic methyl esters (entries 12,13) were also hydrolyzed to the corresponding carboxyl acids in 55–93% yields. Hydrolysis of methyl and ethyl esters of dicarboxylic acids (entries 14,15) was also successful to give the corresponding dicarboxylic acids. Ring-opening hydrolysis of a lactone, 3,4-dihydrocoumarin, gave the product with OH and carboxyl groups (entry 16). As shown in Eqn. (1), the hydrolysis of n-dodecyl acetate gave 79% yields of n-dodecanol and acetic acid. (1) For the standard reaction of 1a to 2a by Hβ-75, we studied the reusability of the Hβ-75 catalyst. After the reaction for 24h (Table 2, entry 4), the catalyst was separated from the mixture by centrifugation, followed by washing with acetone, and by drying at 90°C for 3h. The recovered catalyst was reused four times without a significant loss of its catalytic activity (Fig. 3 ). This indicates that Hβ-75 is a reusable catalyst for this reaction. Table 3 shows the substrate scope for the OD-Hβ-20-catalyzed hydrolysis of esters. For most of the esters, including linear aliphatic esters (entries 1–3), methyl 3-phenylpropionate (entry 4) and benzoates (entries 6,7,10), OD-Hβ-20 showed high yields comparable to those of Hβ-75, but for some of the esters (entries 8,9) OD-Hβ-20 showed lower yields than Hβ-75. 3.4 Factors affecting the activity of Hβ and HZSM5 catalysts The screening study in Table 1 suggests the following factors affecting the catalytic activity of zeolites for the hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters: (1) hydrophobicity due to high Si/Al ratio or immobilized alkyl groups, (2) three-dimensional large pore structure, and (3) strong Brønsted acid sites. To show the importance of these factors, we will show the catalytic activity of Hβ and HZSM5 catalysts with different Si/Al ratios for hydrolysis of esters with different sizes. Fig. 4 shows time-yield profiles for Hβ-75 and HZSM5-75-catalyzed hydrolysis of esters with different molecular sizes. As shown in the supporting information (Fig. S1), we estimated the diameter of the minimum cross-section of the ester, hereafter called size of the ester. The reaction rates estimated from the time-yield profiles are plotted as a function of the size of the esters (Fig. 5 ). For Hβ-75 having the pore size of 7.6Å×7.3Å, methyl laurate (5.8Å×5.3Å) and methyl 3-phenylpropionate 1a (6.8Å×5.2Å) with sizes less than the pore size were smoothly converted to the corresponding carboxylic acids. Methyl 1-naphthaleneacetate (8.0Å×5.8Å) with size slightly larger than the pore size gave slightly lower reaction rate than 1a, and methyl diphenylacetate with much larger size (10.6Å×10.6Å) did not react. For HZSM5-75 with pore size of 5.6Å×5.3Å, the reaction rate decreased with increase in the size of the ester. For the esters with the size smaller than 8.0Å×5.8Å, the reaction rates by Hβ-75 were higher than those by HZSM5-75. Taking into account the previously established fact that the strength of Brønsted acid sites in Hβ and HZSM5 is close to each other [28–30], these results clearly indicate that the pore size is a critical factor; the active zeolite catalyst should have a pore size comparable to or larger than the size of the ester. Fig. 6 compares the reaction rates for hydrolysis of methyl laurate and methyl 3-phenylpropionate 1a as a function of Si/Al ratios in Hβ and HZSM5 catalysts. For both substrates, Hβ catalysts show higher reaction rates than HZSM5 catalysts, indicating again that the larger pore size of Hβ results in higher activity than HZSM5. For both zeolites and both substrates, an intermediate Si/Al ratio of 75 gave the highest catalytic activity. The low activity for the Si-rich zeolites can be due to smaller numbers of the Brønsted acid sites. Below Si/Al ratio of 75, the activity increases with Si/Al ratio, possibly due to an increase in the hydrophobicity of the zeolites with the Si/Al ratio. In order to evaluate the hydrophobicity of the Hβ zeolites, we carried out adsorption experiment of 1-pentanol in water for the Hβ catalysts with different Si/Al ratios. Fig. 7 shows the number of 1-pentanol adsorbed on the catalysts after stirring the mixture of Hβ (0.1g) and 1-pentanol (1.0mmol) in water (1.0mL) for 24h at room temperature. The number of 1-pentanol adsorbed increased with the Si/Al ratio. The result indicates that the hydrophobicity of the Hβ zeolites increases with the Si/Al ratio. This tendency is consistent with that observed by Otomo et al. [22]; they have shown that hydrophilicity of Hβ zeolites, estimated by vapor-phase water adsorption experiments, decreases with increase in the Si/Al ratio. Summarizing the above results, we can conclude that the hydrophobicity, pore size and number of Brønsted acid sites are critical factors affecting the catalytic activity of Hβ and HZSM5 zeolites for hydration of water insoluble esters. The high activity of the Hβ with moderate Si/Al ratio (75) is due to its hydrophobicity, large pore size and moderate number of the Brønsted acid sites. 3.5 Origin of higher catalytic activity of Hβ-75 than homogeneous Brønsted acids The screening study in Table 1 demonstrates that Hβ-75 shows higher yield than the conventional homogeneous Brønsted acids. Fig. 8 compares time-yield profiles for hydrolysis of 1a by 10mg of Hβ-75, H2SO4 and PTSA. It is important to note that most of the hydrophobic ester 1a is on water and the solid acids are suspended in water. The homogeneous Brønsted acids, H2SO4 and PTSA, showed higher initial rates than Hβ-75. However, the yields for the homogeneous catalysts leveled off after 10h, whereas the yield for Hβ-75 linearly increased with time. Consequently, the final yield for Hβ-75 was higher than those for the homogeneous catalysts. It is reasonable to assume that the dissolution rate of 1a from oil droplets on water into water phase does not depend on the amount of 1a on water (zero-order kinetic). Hence, the unusual zero-order kinetics for Hβ-75 in Fig. 8 can be explained assuming that the rates of 1a adsorption in Hβ-75 and its hydrolysis are higher than the rate of 1a dissolution into water. After 24h of the reaction by Hβ-75, followed by removal of the catalyst from the liquid, the liquid consisted of two phases of water and oil on water. Considering the full conversion of 1a and 94% yield of the corresponding carboxylic acid 2a, it is obvious that the oil phase consists of the product 2a. Fig. 9 compares the catalytic activity of Hβ-75 and H2SO4 for hydrolysis of 1a on/in water and in diglyme (0.7mL)/H2O(0.3mL) mixture. Initially, most of the ester 1a was on water in the former conditions, while 1a was completely dissolved in the diglyme/H2O mixture (single phase) in the latter conditions. For H2SO4, the yield of 2a was nearly independent on the presence of diglyme, whereas the presence of diglyme significantly decreased the yield for Hβ-75. The product 2a dissolved in the diglyme/H2O phase can undergo reverse esterification catalyzed by Brønsted acid sites of Hβ-75, which can result in the low yield in the diglyme/H2O condition. For the diglyme-free conditions, in contrast, most of the products 2a move to the oil phase, and hence the reverse esterification does not occur because of the absence of Hβ-75 in the oil droplets. Summarizing the above results, we can conclude that the inhibition of the reverse esterification by phase separation is primary responsible for the high yield of carboxylic acids for Hβ-75-catalyzed hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters on/in water. Another possible reason of the high yields for Hβ-75 will be preferential interaction of the hydrophobic pore of Hβ-75 with the hydrophobic esters over less hydrophobic products (carboxylic acids and methanol). This hypothesis is verified by the adsorption experiments of 1a on/in water into hydrophobic zeolites (Hβ-75 and OD-Hβ-20) and a hydrophilic solid acid (SiO2-Al2O3) shown in Fig. 10 . The numbers of the ester adsorbed in the hydrophobic zeolites were larger than those on the hydrophilic SiO2-Al2O3. The mixture used for the adsorption experiments is the same as that for the catalytic tests in Fig. 8; most of the hydrophobic ester 1a is initially on water and the solid acids are suspended in water. Hence, the relatively large number of 1a adsorbed in Hβ-75 (1.2mmolg−1) indicates that Hβ-75 selectively adsorbs the dilute ester 1a in the presence of excess water probably due to interaction between less polar Si-O-Si surface and the hydrophobic ester. In contrast, the surface of SiO2-Al2O3, consisting of hydrophilic hydroxyl groups, can interact more preferentially with water than the ester 1a, resulting in its low adsorption capacity for 1a. The relatively large adsorption capacity of OD-Hβ-20 (1.1mmolg−1) also indicates that the adsorption of 1a is driven by hydrophobic interaction between the solid and the ester. To study the effect of amphiphilic co-solvent on the adsorption capacity of Hβ-75, we tested the adsorption experiment for Hβ-75 in a diglyme (0.7mL)/H2O (0.3mL) mixture. The co-presence of excess amount of the diglyme (4.9 equiv. with respect to 1a) decreased the adsorption amount of 1a in Hβ-75, which could be due to competitive adsorption of diglyme and 1a on the same Si-O-Si sites. This confirms that the hydrophobic interaction between the hydrophobic zeolite and the ester is the primary important factor affecting the adsorption capacity of the zeolite. The result shows that inhibition effect of diglyme on the ester adsorption in Hβ-75 is also responsible for the low yield for the hydrolysis of 1a by Hβ-75 in diglyme/H2O (Fig. 9). From the above results, the high yield of carboxylic acids for Hβ-75-catalyzed hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters in/on water is rationalized as follows. In water, inner surface of the high-silica zeolite interacts more preferentially with hydrophobic esters than polar molecules (carboxylic acids, water, methanol). Hence, the local concentration of the esters around the Brønsted acids sites of Hβ-75 is higher than those of carboxylic acid and methanol. Because of low solubility of the carboxylic acids (in Table 2) in water, the carboxylic acids move to the oil droplets on water. Both of the phase separation phenomena inhibit the reverse esterification of the carboxylic acids with methanol, leading to the high yields of the carboxylic acids. Fig. 11 compares adsorption capacity of hydrophobic zeolites (Hβ-75 and OD-Hβ-20) and hydrophilic SiO2-Al2O3 for a water soluble ester (ethyl acetate) and acetic acid at room temperature. The hydrophobic zeolites showed larger adsorption capacity for the ester than acetic acid, and vice versa for the hydrophilic solid (SiO2-Al2O3). This result is consistent with the above discussion. 4 Conclusion Hβ zeolite with a moderate Si/Al ratio (Si/Al=75), Hβ-75, is a reusable and effective catalyst for hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters on/in water. The hydrophobicity, pore size and number of Brønsted acid sites are critical factors affecting the catalytic activity for hydration of water-insoluble esters. The high yields by Hβ-75 are due to preferential interaction of the hydrophobic zeolite pore with hydrophobic esters over polar molecules (carboxylic acids, water, alcohols) and transfer of the carboxylic acids to the oil droplets on water, both of which inhibit the reverse reaction (esterification of the carboxylic acids). coredata.dc:description: Hydrolysis of water-insoluble esters is an industrially important but challenging reaction, because the esters are mostly present in oil droplets on water during the reaction. On the basis of the screening results for hydrolysis of a water-insoluble ester, 3-phenylpropionate, on/in water by 25 types of heterogeneous and homogenous catalysts, we have found that Hβ zeolite with a moderate Si/Al ratio (Si/Al=75), Hβ-75, is an effective and reusable catalyst for hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters. The hydrolysis of esters with different sizes is studied by Hβ and HZSM5 zeolites with different Si/Al ratios, and the results show the hydrophobicity, pore size and number of Brønsted acid sites are critical factors affecting the catalytic activity for this system. Kinetic and adsorption studies show that the high yields by Hβ-75 are due to preferential interaction of the hydrophobic zeolite pore with hydrophobic esters over polar molecules (carboxylic acids, water, alcohols) and transfer of the carboxylic acids to the oil droplets on water, both of which inhibit the reverse reaction (esterification of the carboxylic acids).
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic hydrolysis of hydrophobic esters on/in water by high-silica large pore zeolites
